subtitles.text: Fai schifo cucinare, ja totalmente schifo!
Today we're not making spaghetti carbonara.
Some might say it looks like carbonara, and tastes like carbonara, and has the mouthfeel of carbonara, the substances which make up carbonara, and even the personality of carbonara.
But this is not carbonara.
The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.
That's how you know this isn't carbonara, because if you were making carbonara, you'd be using guanciale.
You see, bacon comes from a pig, whereas guanciale comes from a completely different animal, known as an Italian hog.
Oh my god, it looks like a jumping Italian horse!
You wouldn't make a hamburger with tiger meat, would you?
I really hope not.
Tigers are expensive.
Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.
Don't accidentally use egg yolkles, because banjo music really ruins this dish.
We'll just do the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick.
You can also do the back and forth, and whoops, maybe no forth.
Then make the traditional Italian egg white on toast as an appetizer.
Mmm.
This is pecorino romano, which you would use if you're making carbonara, which we are not.
It gets its name because the Romans who made it had huge pecs.
So did the goats.
They worked out together.
If you want to shred your pecorino more easily, you can take a drill, put in a nice big fat screw, then you just... okay.
So, whoop.
All right.
If I just maybe... okay, let's try.
Nope.
Hmm.
See, in my mind when I thought of this, none of the physics of how objects work would be an issue.
If you're Italian, you don't need to innovate in this department, because you simply harness the power of your hand gesture muscles, which makes this a breeze.
So grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.
Then we'll add some pepper pepper pepper, and we're good to go.
And by go, I mean stay, because we're not done yet.
The original carbonara was made with handcrafted artisan spaghetti from the Veneto region.
Each spaghetti craftsperson had their signature style.
Sadly, these days you can only find straight parallel line spaghetti.
And you know, it just really angers me that the craft has been left to die like nobody cares.
Now, let's just fix that.
Breaking spaghetti in half is a crime in Italy and can land you in prison for up to nine months.
It sounds like an overreaction at first, but the crack sends a shock wave through the noodle, rendering it completely inedible.
I mean, look, here's uncracked spaghetti and cracked spaghetti.
If I didn't tell you that was spaghetti, you wouldn't have even recognized it.
Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.
Keep wang jangling that for the first bit to keep the spag from getting clingy.
By the way, spaghetti gets its name because you put it in the spa to cook it.
Now our bacon is cooked.
We're turning the burner off, waiting for this to cool, at least until there's no sizzle left, and a bit longer so we don't overcook the eggbased sauce.
Now I'm gonna put in a bit of pasta water into our sauce ingredients to get that cheeseahead start on the melting.
Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.

Since noodles are made of wheat, this is essentially a bacon sandwich, but if you do strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water, and if you get the kind of spaghetti with dehydrated meatballs, just pull those out and set them aside.

Then the sauce can go in, and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat, although you can put your pan on low to thicken it as well, because here comes more pasta water, making this nice and creamy.
The reason we add pasta water is so that if you get thirsty while you eat it, you don't have to stop and have a drink.
Here I'm trying to do that fancy twist thing, but it's not the right tool, and I don't know what I'm doing.
We'll finish with some pepper pepper pepper, and some more pecorino or parmesan, and here we don't have carbonara.

If you want to really see not carbonara, here's an earlier attempt where I used whole egg, too much heat, and for some reason this came out way worse than my first attempt with whole egg, which came out great.
So are the whims of the food gods.
If this was carbonara, you'd have to be careful, because the carbonistic properties are so fragile, that if you put in a single pea, it would no longer be carbonara.
It's a mysterious chemical reaction that only Italian scientists understand.
I'm craving carbonara, but I don't have guanciale.
Should I really even bother?
Oh no, will they judge my carbonara?
Because I want some cream upon it.
Should I eat it in the closet?
Oh no, what have I done?
I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetablefree.
They say it's no game.
Hang my head as I eat this not carbonara in shame.

steps: Chop bacon into small pieces.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture and mix well.
Boil water in a pot, add salt, and cook spaghetti until al dente.
Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.
Add a small amount of pasta water to the egg yolk and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the pan with bacon.
Mix the spaghetti with the bacon and then add the egg yolk mixture, stirring quickly to coat the pasta and create a creamy sauce.
If needed, add more pasta water to achieve the desired sauce consistency.
Finish with additional grated pecorino romano and black pepper before serving.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Ingredients-1
outcomes: All ingredients are prepared and ready for cooking.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Chop up some bacon. Separate egg yolks from the whites. Grate pecorino romano cheese. Prepare spaghetti and pasta water.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Bacon is used instead of guanciale, which is traditional for carbonara. Egg yolks are typically used in carbonara, but the tutorial emphasizes this is not carbonara. Pecorino romano is mentioned as a traditional ingredient for carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick to separate egg yolks. Grate cheese using hand gesture muscles for ease.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Don't accidentally use egg yolks if not intended, as it can ruin the dish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-2
materials: Whole eggs (visual: whole eggs in shell)
Pecorino Romano cheese (visual: block of cheese)
outcomes: Egg mixture ready for carbonara (visual: creamy yellow mixture)
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Separate the egg yolks from the whites, whisk them together with whole eggs, grate Pecorino Romano cheese into the mixture, and add black pepper.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The egg yolks provide richness and creaminess to the sauce, while the cheese adds flavor and the pepper adds spice.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use the 'hold the yolk with your thumb' trick to separate the yolks easily.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to accidentally use egg yolkles, as it can ruin the dish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-3
materials: Spaghetti: Long, thin cylindrical pasta used as the main ingredient.
Salt: White crystalline substance used to season the boiling water.
outcomes: Cooked spaghetti: The pasta is cooked to al dente, meaning it is firm to the bite, and ready to be combined with other ingredients.
Reserved pasta water: Some of the starchy water from cooking the pasta is saved to be used later in the sauce.
tools: Pot: A large container used to boil water and cook the pasta.
Stove: The appliance used to heat the pot and boil the water.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil water in a pot on the stove. Once boiling, add salt to the water and then add 156 pieces of spaghetti. Stir the spaghetti initially to prevent it from sticking together. Cook the spaghetti until it is al dente. Before draining the spaghetti, reserve some of the pasta water for later use.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The reason for adding pasta water to the sauce is to help create a creamy texture and to ensure the sauce clings to the pasta. The starch in the pasta water helps emulsify the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Stir the spaghetti initially after adding it to the boiling water to prevent it from sticking together.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Do not break the spaghetti in half before cooking, as it is considered a culinary crime in Italy and affects the texture of the pasta.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Bacon-4
materials: Bacon or guanciale, visually described as crispy and cooked
outcomes: Crispy bacon or guanciale, some set aside for garnish
tools: Pan, visually described as used for cooking bacon
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cook the bacon or guanciale in a pan until it is crispy. Once cooked, set aside some pieces for garnish if desired.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Cooking the bacon or guanciale until crispy enhances the texture and flavor of the dish, and setting aside some for garnish adds a visual and textural contrast to the final presentation.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the bacon is cooked to a crispy texture for the best flavor and texture in the dish.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the bacon, as it can become too hard and lose its flavor.

subgoal_summaries.title: Mix Egg and Cheese-5
materials: Egg yolks (visual: bright yellow, thick liquid)
Pecorino Romano cheese (visual: finely grated, white cheese)
outcomes: Creamy egg and cheese mixture (visual: smooth, thick, yellow sauce)
tools: Whisk or fork (visual: metal utensil for mixing)
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Add a bit of pasta water into the egg yolk and grated Pecorino Romano cheese mixture to help the cheese start melting and create a creamy texture.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The pasta water helps the cheese melt and combines with the egg yolks to create a creamy sauce that coats the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use the heat from the pasta water to help melt the cheese and create a smooth sauce.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Ensure the pasta water is not too hot to avoid cooking the eggs prematurely.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Pasta and Bacon-6
materials: Cooked pasta (spaghetti) - visually shown as long, thin noodles
Bacon or guanciale - visually shown as small, crispy pieces
Pasta water - visually shown as a clear liquid
outcomes: Pasta is mixed with bacon and becomes coated with a creamy sauce - visually shown as pasta with a glossy, creamy appearance
tools: Pan - visually shown as a cooking pan on a stove
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Turn off the burner and let the bacon cool. Add a bit of pasta water to the sauce ingredients. Transfer the noodles directly from the water into the bacon pan and mix. Add the sauce and more pasta water to make it creamy.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The reason for adding pasta water is to help the cheese melt and to make the sauce creamy. The heat from the noodles will cook the egg in the sauce just enough.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If you strain the spaghetti, set aside some pasta water to use in the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Make sure the bacon is cool enough before adding the sauce to avoid overcooking the egg-based sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-3
materials: Spaghetti: Straight parallel line spaghetti, 156 pieces.
Salt: Used to salt the water for cooking spaghetti.
outcomes: Cooked spaghetti: Spaghetti cooked until al dente, ready to be mixed with sauce.
tools: Pot: Used to boil water and cook spaghetti.
Stove: Used to heat the pot of water for cooking spaghetti.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Salt the water and bring it to a boil. Add 156 pieces of spaghetti to the boiling water. Stir the spaghetti initially to prevent it from sticking. Cook the spaghetti until it is al dente. Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The reason we add pasta water is to help create a creamy sauce when mixed with the other ingredients later.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Stir the spaghetti initially to prevent it from sticking together.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Breaking spaghetti in half is considered a crime in Italy and can ruin the texture of the pasta.

subgoal_summaries.title: Create Sauce-8
materials: Egg yolks (visual: bright yellow, thick liquid)
Pecorino Romano cheese (visual: finely grated, white cheese)
Black pepper (visual: coarse ground, black specks)
outcomes: Creamy sauce coating the pasta (visual: glossy, smooth sauce covering noodles)
tools: Spoon or spatula for stirring (visual: long-handled utensil)
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Turn off the burner and let the bacon pan cool until there's no sizzle left. Add a bit of pasta water to the sauce ingredients to help melt the cheese. Transfer the cooked pasta directly from the water into the bacon pan and stir. Add the sauce mixture to the pasta, allowing the heat from the noodles to cook the egg just enough. Optionally, put the pan on low heat to thicken the sauce, adding more pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The heat from the noodles is sufficient to cook the egg mixture without scrambling it, creating a creamy sauce. Adding pasta water helps melt the cheese and achieve the desired sauce consistency.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Add pasta water to the sauce ingredients to help the cheese melt and create a creamy texture. Stir the pasta immediately after adding it to the pan to prevent clumping.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Ensure the pan is cool enough before adding the egg mixture to prevent scrambling the eggs. If the pan is too hot, the eggs will cook too quickly and scramble instead of forming a creamy sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Finish and Serve-9
materials: Pecorino or Parmesan cheese, finely grated
outcomes: The pasta dish is creamy and well-coated with sauce.
The dish is garnished with cheese and pepper, enhancing its flavor.
The bacon adds a savory and crispy element to the dish.
tools: Pan for mixing pasta and sauce
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Add pasta water to the sauce ingredients to help melt the cheese. Transfer the noodles directly from the water into the bacon pan and mix. Add the sauce to the noodles, allowing the heat to cook the egg slightly. Optionally, place the pan on low heat to thicken the sauce further. Add more pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency. Finish by adding freshly cracked black pepper and more grated cheese. Garnish with cooked bacon before serving.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Adding pasta water helps melt the cheese and achieve a creamy sauce consistency. The heat from the noodles cooks the egg in the sauce just enough without scrambling it. Additional pasta water can be used to adjust the sauce's creaminess.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use freshly cracked black pepper for better flavor. Adjust the sauce consistency with pasta water to your liking.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Ensure the pan is not too hot when adding the sauce to prevent the eggs from scrambling. Be cautious with the amount of heat used to thicken the sauce.

metadata.title: Not Spaghetti Carbonara - You Suck at Cooking (episode 138)

subtitles.text: You need to understand, carbonara does not need cream, or peas, or ham, or whatever else people are putting in it.
It's so simple!
Today, hang out for a second, and you're gonna learn how to do it right.
Let's not waste any time, now let's go!
Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured.
So for this video, of course, I could have ordered guanciale, but I know most of my audience is American, so I want the most people possible to actually make this, so we're gonna use bacon.
And thick cut bacon would be best.
You could also use pancetta.
So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way.
That's about three quarters of an inch.
Turn this pan on to medium heat.
I'm doing a tiny bit of olive oil, I don't think it's traditional, but when I'm cooking Italian food, it just feels right.
Then go ahead and break your bacon into that pan.
And what we're gonna do here is slowly render out the fat from this bacon, get it nice and crispy.
We'll use most of it in the pasta, and then we'll actually use some for garnish, because who doesn't like crispy bacon on top?
Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit, about a tablespoon of salt, kosher salt, into about four quarts of water.
Usually, I'm gonna put more salt, but because there's so many salty elements in carbonara, I wanna put less salt in the pasta water.
So first is very important, we need to talk about the cheese.
Here we have Pecorino Romano, it's a sheep's milk cheese, this one is aged.
I think this is what is traditionally used when you're making spaghetti carbonara, but as always, if you watch this channel, you know I love ParmigianoReggiano.
That's not to be confused with Parmesan, make sure it says ParmigianoReggiano, and it's from Italy, and you'll know you have the good stuff.

So what I'm gonna do is a mixture of both these cheeses, and you want them to be pretty fine, so I'm gonna be using this cheese grater, and if you don't have one of those, just use this setting on a box grater, and just get to shredding.
I'm gonna do about three ounces of each of these cheeses, so half and half, but as always, with my videos, the full recipe is gonna be down in the description.
Underneath this video, you just gotta click that little arrow, and it'll open up.
So here's all our beautiful cheese.
Okay, now time for the eggs.
A lot of recipes call for all whole, all yolks.
I like to do a mixture of both.
So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks.
The way I see it, carbonara is already so rich, it doesn't need all egg yolks.
Go ahead and whisk that all up, and then we'll start whisking our cheese into our egg mixture.
And you'll see all that, and it looked like so much cheese, right?
But as this breaks down, it won't look like that anymore.
Add that all in.
And so now we have a consistency like this.
Now, this is a very important time for our good friend, Sergeant Gilbert.
I'm gonna put quite a bit of Gilbert's insides into this egg mixture.
If you didn't know already, Gilbert is just fresh ground black pepper.
He's a sentient being, a pepper grinder, who became selfaware in 2020.
You know, and this is preference.
Put as much pepper or as little pepper as you like, and whisk it in.
As you can see, there's a lot of fat coming out of this bacon.
Just want to turn this occasionally.
And we are going to be using some, but not all of this fat in the actual spaghetti carbonara.

steps: Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil (optional).
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Mix the grated cheeses into the egg mixture.
Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan. Turn off the heat.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti to the pan with the bacon using tongs, leaving the pasta water in the pot.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the spaghetti and gently mix to coat the pasta, ensuring the eggs do not scramble.
If needed, use reserved pasta water to adjust the sauce consistency.
Plate the pasta and garnish with additional grated cheese and crispy bacon.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Ingredients-1
materials: Guanciale or thick cut bacon (about a half pound)
Eggs (3 whole eggs and 2 egg yolks)
outcomes: All necessary ingredients are gathered and prepared for making Pasta Carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Gather all necessary ingredients: guanciale or thick cut bacon, Pecorino Romano cheese, Parmigiano Reggiano cheese, eggs, kosher salt, fresh ground black pepper, and olive oil. Prepare the ingredients by slicing the bacon, grating the cheese, and separating the eggs. Mix the grated cheese with the eggs and season with black pepper.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The choice of ingredients is based on traditional recipes and availability. Guanciale is traditional, but bacon is used for accessibility. Pecorino Romano is traditional, but a mix with Parmigiano Reggiano is preferred for flavor. The mixture of whole eggs and yolks balances richness.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use thick cut bacon for better texture. Grate cheese finely for better integration into the egg mixture. Adjust the amount of black pepper to taste.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Do not use cream, peas, or ham as they are not traditional ingredients for carbonara.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Bacon-2
outcomes: Bacon is crispy and some is set aside for garnish
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Turn the pan on to medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil. Break the bacon into the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy. Set some crispy bacon aside for garnish and drain it on a paper towel. Turn off the heat and drain off most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Rendering the fat slowly allows the bacon to become crispy, which is desirable for both the pasta and as a garnish. Leaving some fat in the pan will help flavor the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use thick cut bacon for better texture and flavor. You can also use pancetta as an alternative.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the bacon. Turn the heat down towards the end to avoid burning.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-3
outcomes: Spaghetti cooked to slightly al dente, ready to be finished in the bacon pan
Reserved pasta water for adjusting sauce consistency
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Bring a pot of water to a boil and season it with about a tablespoon of kosher salt. Add the spaghetti to the boiling water and cook it for about 10 minutes until it is slightly al dente. Reserve the pasta water for later use.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The pasta is cooked slightly al dente because it will be finished in the bacon pan, allowing it to absorb flavors and achieve the perfect texture. The pasta water is reserved because it can be used to adjust the sauce's consistency, making it creamy without adding cream.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use cheap Italian brands of pasta as they are preferred for their quality and cost-effectiveness. If the sauce is too thick, add a little reserved pasta water to loosen it and achieve a creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the pasta as it will continue to cook when mixed with the sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-4
outcomes: A well-mixed egg and cheese mixture with a creamy consistency, ready to be combined with pasta.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Separate two egg yolks and combine them with three whole eggs in a bowl. Whisk the eggs together until well combined. Gradually whisk in the finely grated Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses until the mixture is smooth. Add a generous amount of freshly ground black pepper to taste and whisk it into the mixture.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The mixture of whole eggs and yolks provides richness without being overly heavy. The combination of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses adds depth of flavor. Freshly ground black pepper enhances the taste and adds a subtle heat.
subgoal_summaries.tips: You can adjust the amount of black pepper according to your preference. If the mixture seems too thick, you can add a little pasta water to loosen it up.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to scramble the eggs when mixing them with the pasta later. The heat from the pasta will gently cook the eggs, creating a creamy sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Bacon-2
outcomes: Bacon is crispy and some is set aside for garnish
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Turn the pan on to medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil. Break the bacon into the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy. Set some bacon aside for garnish and drain it on a paper towel. Turn off the heat and drain off most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Rendering the fat slowly allows the bacon to become crispy, which is desirable for both the pasta and as a garnish. Leaving some fat in the pan will help flavor the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use thick cut bacon for better texture and flavor. You can also use pancetta as an alternative.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the bacon. Turn the heat down towards the end to avoid burning.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-3
outcomes: Spaghetti cooked to slightly al dente
Reserved pasta water for later use
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Bring a pot of water to a boil. Add about a tablespoon of kosher salt to the water. Once boiling, add the spaghetti and cook for about 10 minutes until slightly al dente. Reserve the pasta water for later use.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The pasta should be cooked slightly al dente because it will finish cooking in the bacon pan. Reserving pasta water is important as it can be used to adjust the consistency of the sauce later.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use cheap Italian brands of pasta for better results. If the sauce is too thick, add a little reserved pasta water to loosen it up.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the pasta as it will continue to cook in the sauce later.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Pasta and Bacon-7
materials: cooked pasta (spaghetti) - visually shown as cooked and drained spaghetti
bacon or guanciale - visually shown as crispy bacon pieces
egg and cheese mixture - visually shown as a creamy mixture of eggs and cheese
pasta water - visually shown as reserved water from cooking pasta
outcomes: Pasta is coated in a creamy, velvety sauce without scrambling the eggs - visually shown as pasta with a smooth, creamy coating
The dish is ready to be plated and garnished - visually shown as pasta being served on a plate with garnishes
tools: pan - visually shown as a pan used to cook bacon and mix pasta
tongs - visually shown as a tool to transfer pasta
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Transfer the cooked pasta into the pan with the bacon, ensuring the heat is off. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta, stirring gently to coat the pasta without scrambling the eggs. If the sauce is too thick, add a little pasta water to loosen it and create a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The heat from the pasta will gently cook the eggs, creating a creamy sauce without scrambling them. Adding pasta water helps emulsify the sauce and adjust its consistency.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If the sauce doesn't thicken as desired, you can place the pan over simmering pasta water to gently heat it further. Use pasta water to adjust the sauce's consistency if it's too thick.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Ensure the heat is off when adding the egg mixture to prevent scrambling the eggs. Be gentle with the pasta to avoid breaking it.

subgoal_summaries.title: Create Sauce-8
materials: egg and cheese mixture (made from Pecorino Romano, Parmigiano Reggiano, eggs, and black pepper)
outcomes: A creamy sauce that coats the pasta without scrambling the eggs.
tools: pan (preferably a thick one like La Crusade)
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Once the spaghetti is cooked and transferred to the pan, add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta. Stir gently to combine, allowing the heat from the pasta to cook the eggs and create a creamy sauce. Be careful not to scramble the eggs. If the sauce is too thick, add a little pasta water to loosen it.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The heat from the pasta will gently cook the eggs, creating a creamy sauce without scrambling them. The pasta water can be used to adjust the sauce's consistency.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If the sauce doesn't thicken as desired, you can place the pan over simmering pasta water to gently heat it further, similar to a double boiler. This is especially useful if your pan doesn't retain heat well.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to scramble the eggs by ensuring the heat is off and stirring gently.

subgoal_summaries.title: Finish and Serve-9
materials: Pecorino Romano cheese (sheep's milk cheese, aged)
outcomes: A creamy, velvety sauce that coats the pasta without scrambling the eggs
A beautifully plated dish with additional cheese and crispy bacon garnish
subgoal_summaries.instructions: After cooking the pasta, add the egg and cheese mixture to the hot pasta, ensuring the eggs do not scramble. Stir gently to create a creamy sauce. If the sauce is too thick, add a little pasta water to loosen it. Plate the pasta and finish with additional Parmigiano Reggiano and crispy bacon as garnish.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The heat from the pasta will cook the eggs gently, creating a creamy sauce without scrambling. Adding pasta water can help adjust the sauce's consistency.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If the sauce doesn't thicken as desired, you can place the pan over simmering pasta water to gently cook the egg mixture further. Adding pasta water can also help achieve the desired sauce consistency.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to scramble the eggs when mixing them with the hot pasta. Handle the pasta gently to avoid breaking it.

steps: Gather the ingredients: guanciale (or pancetta), pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.
Boil water for the pasta, adding a small amount of salt.
Twist the pasta and place it into the boiling water to prevent sticking. Cook for 8 minutes.
Prepare the guanciale by removing the skin and slicing it into 1 cm thick pieces, then chop into 0.5 cm chunks.
Place the guanciale in a cold pan and turn the heat to medium-high to render the fat.
Crack a garlic clove and add it to the pan with the guanciale to infuse flavor.
Crack black peppercorns using a pestle and mortar, then sift to use the hotter inner part of the peppercorns.
Once the guanciale is golden, remove the garlic from the pan.
Crack eggs into a bowl and add 20 grams of pecorino romano cheese. Whisk together.
Turn off the heat under the guanciale pan and add the cooked pasta directly from the pot, along with some pasta water, to the pan.
Stir the pasta with the guanciale and fat, allowing the water and fat to emulsify into a creamy sauce.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta, stirring quickly to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Adjust the sauce consistency by adding more pasta water if needed, ensuring a creamy texture.
Finish with additional cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino romano cheese before serving.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Ingredients-1
outcomes: All necessary ingredients are gathered and prepared for cooking.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Gather the following ingredients: guanciale, pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic. Prepare the guanciale by removing the skin and slicing it into chunks. Crack the peppercorns using a pestle and mortar and sift them to separate the milder outer skin from the hotter inside part.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Guanciale is preferred for its fat content which is essential for the dish. Pecorino Romano is more classic than parmesan for carbonara. The fat from guanciale and the cheese are salty, so only a tiny amount of salt is needed in the pasta water. Cracking and sifting the peppercorns ensures the use of the hotter inside part for a spicier flavor.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Try to get guanciale with the fat intact as it is needed for the dish. Use a pestle and mortar to crack peppercorns for better flavor.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be cautious with the amount of salt added to the pasta water due to the saltiness of the cheese and guanciale.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-2
outcomes: Pasta cooked until al dente
Reserved pasta water
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Grab the pasta by two hands, twist it into the boiling water to prevent sticking, and add a tiny amount of salt. Cook the pasta for eight minutes until al dente. Reserve some pasta water before draining.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Twisting the pasta into the water prevents it from sticking together. Adding only a tiny amount of salt is important because the cheese and guanciale are already salty. The reserved pasta water is used to emulsify the sauce later.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Twisting the pasta as you add it to the water helps prevent it from sticking together.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be cautious with the amount of salt added to the pasta water due to the saltiness of other ingredients.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Ingredients-1
outcomes: All necessary ingredients are gathered and prepared for cooking.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Gather the following ingredients: guanciale, pecorino romano, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic. Prepare the guanciale by removing the skin and slicing it into chunks. Crack the peppercorns using a pestle and mortar and sift them to separate the outer skin from the hotter inner part.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Guanciale is preferred for its fat content which is essential for the dish. Pecorino Romano is more classic than parmesan for carbonara. The outer skin of the peppercorn is milder, and the inner part is hotter, which is ideal for carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Try to get guanciale with the fat intact as it is needed for the dish.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Eggs are delicate and need to be treated carefully to avoid ending up with stir-fried noodles instead of a creamy sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Bacon-4
outcomes: Crispy guanciale
Rendered fat from guanciale
Guanciale with a golden color
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Start with a cold pan and turn it on to medium-high heat. Add the guanciale to the pan to render the fat out. Optionally, add a cracked garlic clove to the pan. Cook until the guanciale is golden and crispy.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Starting with a cold pan allows the fat to render out from the guanciale as it heats up. The garlic is added to infuse the fat with its aroma.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pan is cold before starting to render the fat from the guanciale.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-5
materials: Eggs: free-range, organic, visually described as delicate
Pecorino Romano cheese: sheep's cheese, crumbly, salty
Black pepper: cracked, with the hotter inside part of the peppercorn used
outcomes: A well-mixed egg mixture with pecorino and black pepper, ready to be combined with pasta
tools: Bowl: used to crack and mix the eggs
Whisk: used to whisk the eggs and cheese together
Pestle and mortar: used to crack the peppercorns
Sieve: used to separate the milder outer skin of the peppercorns from the hotter inside part
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Crack the eggs into a bowl. Add about 20 grams of pecorino cheese to the eggs. Whisk the mixture together. Crack the peppercorns using a pestle and mortar, then use a sieve to separate the milder outer skin from the hotter inside part of the peppercorns. Add the hotter part to the egg mixture.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Eggs are delicate and need to be treated carefully to avoid ending up with a texture similar to stir-fried noodles. The hotter inside part of the peppercorn is preferred for a good hot carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use free-range organic eggs for better quality. Use pecorino romano for a more classic taste. Separate the hotter inside part of the peppercorns for a spicier flavor.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: If eggs are not treated right, the dish may end up with a texture similar to stir-fried noodles, which is undesirable.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Bacon-4
outcomes: Crispy guanciale with rendered fat
Some guanciale set aside for garnish
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Remove the skin from the guanciale and slice it into 1 cm pieces. Roughly chop these slices into 0.5 cm chunks. Place the guanciale in a cold pan and turn the heat to medium-high to render the fat. Add a cracked garlic clove to the pan. Cook until the guanciale is golden and crispy.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Starting with a cold pan allows the fat to render out slowly, which is essential for achieving the right texture and flavor. The garlic is added to infuse the fat with its aroma.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the guanciale is not too lean, as the fat is necessary for the dish. You can set aside some crispy guanciale for garnish if desired.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-5
materials: Free-range organic eggs, visually described as delicate
Pecorino Romano cheese, visually described as crumbly and salty
Black pepper, visually described as having an outer skin and a hotter inside part
outcomes: A well-mixed egg mixture with pecorino and black pepper, ready to be combined with pasta
tools: Bowl, visually described as a container to crack eggs into
Whisk, visually described as a tool to mix the eggs and cheese
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Crack the eggs into a bowl. Add about 20 grams of pecorino cheese to the eggs. Whisk the mixture until well combined.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Eggs are delicate and need to be treated carefully to avoid ending up with a scrambled texture instead of a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: If the eggs are not treated right, you may end up with a scrambled texture instead of a creamy sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Bacon-4
outcomes: Crispy guanciale
Rendered fat from guanciale
Guanciale with attitude and color
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Start with a cold pan and turn it on to medium-high heat. Add the guanciale to the pan to render the fat out. Optionally, add a cracked garlic clove to the pan. Cook until the guanciale is golden and crispy. Remove the garlic before proceeding.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Starting with a cold pan allows the fat to render out from the guanciale as it heats up. The garlic is added to infuse the fat with its aroma. The goal is to achieve a crispy texture and a golden color for the guanciale, which contributes to the flavor and texture of the dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pan is cold before starting to render the fat from the guanciale. This helps in achieving the right texture and flavor.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Pasta and Bacon-9
outcomes: Pasta is mixed with bacon or guanciale, creating a creamy sauce through emulsification.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Turn off the heat and drag the pasta and some pasta water into the pan with the bacon or guanciale. Use the water to stop the frying and create a creamy sauce by emulsifying the water with the fat.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The water and fat emulsify to create a creamy sauce, which is essential for the carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use the pasta water to stop the frying process and help emulsify the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Ensure the heat is off before adding the pasta and water to prevent frying.

subgoal_summaries.title: Create Sauce-10
outcomes: A creamy carbonara sauce that coats the pasta without scrambling the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Turn off the heat and drag the pasta and some of the cooking water into the pan with the guanciale fat. Use the water to stop the frying. Add the egg mixture to the pasta and stir, adding more cooking water as needed to create a creamy sauce through emulsification.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The water and fat emulsify to create a creamy sauce. The heat is turned off to prevent the eggs from scrambling, allowing them to gently cook and thicken the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Add more cooking water as needed to achieve the desired creaminess through emulsification.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Ensure the heat is off before adding the egg mixture to prevent scrambling the eggs.

subgoal_summaries.title: Finish and Serve-11
outcomes: Pasta Carbonara with creamy sauce consistency
Garnished with cheese and pepper
Garnished with bacon
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Finish the pasta by adjusting the sauce consistency. Add more cooking water to the pan to emulsify with the fat, creating a creamy sauce. Toss the pasta and add the egg mixture. Finish by adding more black pepper and pecorino cheese. Garnish with bacon before serving.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The creaminess of the sauce is achieved through the emulsification of the cooking water and the fat from the bacon. The technique and timing are crucial to avoid frying the eggs and to achieve the right consistency.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use the cooking water to stop the frying process and help emulsify the sauce. Timing is crucial to achieve the right consistency without frying the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to fry the eggs, as this will result in a scrambled texture instead of a creamy sauce.

metadata.title: How to Make Classic Carbonara | Jamie Oliver

subtitles.text: I am Antonio Carluccio.
Welcome to my kitchen.
I show you how to make the real Carbonara.
Most of the people, they get it wrong, and I will show you why.
Now, this is boiling water to which we add in the ratio of 10 grams per liter of water, salt.
Has to be like this.
And immediately then, we put in, has to be boiling, a pasta.
In this case, it's sort of spaghettoni, the biggest size of spaghetti.
While this is cooking, it takes good 10 minutes, and no oil, please.
No oil, because you don't need it.
You just need to stir a little bit when it's in it, and that's it.
Now, for the original Carbonara, you need the guanciale, which is the cheek, the pork cheek.
And the Romans, they're very special in that because they do it, they cure it like ham, or like pancetta, and it's very tender, very tasty and tender.
Now, you have to cut it in chunks.
You can use naturally also pancetta, the normal pancetta, which is this one here.
But I like the guanciale when I have it, obviously.
And this is the recipe for two people.
Big chunks.
The Romans, they are mad for this pasta.
If there is a Roman pasta, it is this one here.
This is quite a lot for two people, let's see.
And the only thing you have to do now to make the sauce is to take good olive oil, put it in the pan.
There you go.
Put the guanciale into that, and this is the beginning of the sauce, and mostly also the end of it.
Because the rest is coming here into that bowl.
And now you take some good eggs, and for two people you take two eggs.
Oh, lovely colour, look at this.
To be a little bit naughty, I take just the yolk, and we beat it.

steps: Boil water and add salt at a ratio of 10 grams per liter.
Add spaghettoni to the boiling water and cook for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Cut guanciale (or pancetta) into chunks.
Heat olive oil in a pan and add the guanciale to cook.
In a bowl, beat two egg yolks.
Add grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and abundant pepper to the egg yolks and mix.
Check the pasta for doneness and drain when ready.
Remove excess fat from the cooked guanciale if desired.
Add the cooked pasta to the pan with guanciale and mix to cool slightly.
Pour the egg mixture over the pasta and stir to coat, ensuring the pasta is not too hot to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Serve with additional grated parmesan or pecorino and a touch of pepper for decoration.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-1
outcomes: Pasta cooked until al dente
Reserved pasta water
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil water and add salt in the ratio of 10 grams per liter. Once the water is boiling, add the spaghettoni pasta. Cook the pasta for about 10 minutes until it is al dente. Stir occasionally. Reserve some pasta water before draining.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Oil is not needed when cooking pasta; stirring is sufficient to prevent sticking.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Stir the pasta occasionally while it cooks to prevent it from sticking together.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Do not add oil to the pasta water.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Ingredients-2
outcomes: All ingredients are prepared and ready for cooking the Carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Gather all necessary ingredients: guanciale or pancetta, olive oil, eggs, parmesan or pecorino cheese, and pepper. Cut the guanciale into chunks. Beat the eggs in a bowl and mix with cheese and pepper.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Guanciale is preferred for its tenderness and flavor, but pancetta can be used as an alternative. Eggs are used without cream to maintain authenticity. Parmesan or pecorino cheese adds flavor, and pepper is for seasoning.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use guanciale for a more authentic taste. Beat only the yolks of the eggs for a richer sauce.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Do not add cream to the egg mixture as it is not part of the traditional recipe.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Bacon-3
materials: Guanciale or pancetta (pork cheek or normal pancetta)
outcomes: Bacon or guanciale is crispy
Some bacon or guanciale is set aside for garnish
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cook the guanciale or pancetta in a pan until it is crispy. Optionally, set aside some of the cooked bacon for garnish.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The bacon or guanciale is cooked to add flavor to the pasta and to create the base of the sauce. The fat rendered from the bacon can be used to coat the pasta, enhancing its flavor.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If you do not want too much fat in the dish, you can absorb some of it with a paper towel.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overheat the guanciale as it can become too hot and affect the final texture of the dish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-4
materials: Eggs: Two eggs with a lovely color, used for the sauce.
Parmesan cheese: Used to add flavor to the egg mixture.
Pecorino cheese: An alternative to Parmesan, used in Rome, grated for the sauce.
Black pepper: Added abundantly to the egg mixture for seasoning.
outcomes: Egg mixture: A creamy sauce made from eggs, cheese, and pepper, without any cream, ready to coat the pasta.
tools: Bowl: Used to mix the eggs, cheese, and pepper.
Whisk: Used to beat the egg yolks and whole eggs together.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Separate the egg yolks and beat them with whole eggs in a bowl. Add a little bit of Parmesan cheese, or alternatively, pecorino cheese, and abundant black pepper. Stir the mixture to combine.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: No cream is added to the egg mixture because it is absolutely forbidden in the traditional recipe. The cheese and eggs create a creamy texture without the need for cream.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Do not add any cream to the egg mixture as it is not part of the traditional Carbonara recipe.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-1
materials: Salt (10 grams per liter of water)
outcomes: Pasta cooked until al dente
Reserved pasta water
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil water in a pot. Add salt to the boiling water at a ratio of 10 grams per liter. Once the water is boiling, add the spaghettoni pasta. Cook the pasta for about 10 minutes until it is al dente. Reserve some of the pasta water before draining.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The pasta should be cooked until al dente to ensure it has the right texture for the dish. No oil is needed in the water as it is unnecessary and stirring the pasta is sufficient to prevent sticking.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Stir the pasta a little bit while it is cooking to prevent it from sticking together.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Do not add oil to the pasta water as it is not needed.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Bacon-3
materials: Guanciale or pancetta (pork cheek or normal pancetta)
outcomes: Bacon or guanciale is cooked until crispy
Some bacon or guanciale is set aside for garnish if desired
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cook the guanciale or pancetta in a pan until it is crispy. If you want to reduce the fat, use a paper towel to absorb some of it. Set aside some of the crispy bacon or guanciale for garnish if desired.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The guanciale or pancetta is cooked to create the base of the sauce, and its fat adds flavor to the dish. Reducing the fat is optional and can be done if you prefer a less greasy dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If you want to reduce the amount of fat in the dish, use a paper towel to absorb some of the fat from the cooked guanciale or pancetta.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overheat the guanciale or pancetta, as it can become too hot and affect the final texture of the dish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Pasta and Bacon-7
outcomes: Pasta is mixed with bacon or guanciale, absorbing the flavors and slightly cooling down.
The pasta is coated with the egg mixture without scrambling the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Take the cooked pasta and add it to the pan with the bacon or guanciale. Mix them together, allowing the pasta to absorb the flavors. Let it cool slightly to ensure the egg mixture coats the pasta without scrambling.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The pasta should not be too hot when mixed with the egg mixture to prevent the eggs from scrambling. The goal is to coat the pasta with the egg mixture to achieve a creamy texture without actually cooking the eggs into a scramble.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Let the pasta cool slightly in the pan with the bacon to ensure the right temperature for mixing with the egg mixture.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Ensure the pasta is not too hot when adding the egg mixture to avoid scrambling the eggs.

subgoal_summaries.title: Create Sauce-8
materials: Eggs (two eggs for two people, using just the yolk)
outcomes: The pasta is coated with a creamy sauce without the eggs scrambling.
tools: Bowl (for mixing egg yolks and cheese)
subgoal_summaries.instructions: After cooking the pasta, let it cool slightly by stirring it with the guanciale. Then, add the egg mixture to the pasta and stir continuously to coat the pasta with the sauce. Ensure the pasta is not too hot to prevent the eggs from scrambling.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The pasta should not be too hot when adding the egg mixture to prevent the eggs from scrambling. The goal is to create a creamy sauce without using cream, which is traditionally forbidden in Carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Let the pasta cool slightly before adding the egg mixture to ensure the eggs coat the pasta without scrambling.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Avoid having the pasta too hot when adding the egg mixture, as this will cause the eggs to scramble instead of forming a creamy sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Finish and Serve-9
outcomes: The pasta carbonara is creamy and well-coated with the sauce.
The dish is garnished with cheese and pepper, enhancing its flavor and presentation.
The carbonara is ready to be served, showcasing a traditional and authentic appearance.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Adjust the sauce consistency by stirring the pasta with the sauce until it is creamy. Add grated Parmesan or Pecorino cheese and ground black pepper to the pasta. Garnish with the cooked guanciale or pancetta before serving.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The cheese and pepper are added for flavor and decoration, enhancing the traditional taste of the carbonara. The sauce should be creamy without adding cream, which is a common mistake.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use either Parmesan or Pecorino cheese based on your preference for a different flavor profile. Adding a nice touch of pepper can enhance the decoration and taste.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Ensure the pasta is not too hot when mixing with the egg-based sauce to prevent the eggs from scrambling.

subgoal_definitions.title: Prepare Ingredients
subgoal_definitions.description: Gather all necessary ingredients and prepare them for cooking.
original_steps: Gather the ingredients: guanciale (or pancetta), pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.
Cut guanciale (or pancetta) into chunks.
Prepare the guanciale by removing the skin and slicing it into 1 cm thick pieces, then chop into 0.5 cm chunks.
Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Chop bacon into small pieces.

subgoal_definitions.title: Cook Bacon
subgoal_definitions.description: Cook the bacon or guanciale until crispy, and set aside some for garnish if desired.
original_steps: Heat olive oil in a pan and add the guanciale to cook.
Remove excess fat from the cooked guanciale if desired.
Place the guanciale in a cold pan and turn the heat to medium-high to render the fat.
Crack a garlic clove and add it to the pan with the guanciale to infuse flavor.
Once the guanciale is golden, remove the garlic from the pan.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil (optional).
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan. Turn off the heat.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.

subgoal_definitions.title: Prepare Egg Mixture
subgoal_definitions.description: Separate egg yolks, whisk with whole eggs, and mix with cheese and black pepper.
original_steps: In a bowl, beat two egg yolks.
Add grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and abundant pepper to the egg yolks and mix.
Crack eggs into a bowl and add 20 grams of pecorino romano cheese. Whisk together.
Crack black peppercorns using a pestle and mortar, then sift to use the hotter inner part of the peppercorns.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese.
Mix the grated cheeses into the egg mixture.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture and mix well.

subgoal_definitions.title: Cook Pasta
subgoal_definitions.description: Boil water, cook pasta until al dente, and reserve some pasta water.
original_steps: Boil water and add salt at a ratio of 10 grams per liter.
Add spaghettoni to the boiling water and cook for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Check the pasta for doneness and drain when ready.
Boil water for the pasta, adding a small amount of salt.
Twist the pasta and place it into the boiling water to prevent sticking. Cook for 8 minutes.
Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Boil water in a pot, add salt, and cook spaghetti until al dente.
Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.

subgoal_definitions.title: Mix Egg and Cheese
subgoal_definitions.description: Add pasta water to the egg and cheese mixture to create a creamy texture.
original_steps: Add a small amount of pasta water to the egg yolk and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.

subgoal_definitions.title: Combine Pasta and Bacon
subgoal_definitions.description: Mix cooked pasta with bacon or guanciale in the pan, adding pasta water.
original_steps: Add the cooked pasta to the pan with guanciale and mix to cool slightly.
Turn off the heat under the guanciale pan and add the cooked pasta directly from the pot, along with some pasta water, to the pan.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti to the pan with the bacon using tongs, leaving the pasta water in the pot.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the pan with bacon.

subgoal_definitions.title: Create Sauce
subgoal_definitions.description: Add egg mixture to pasta, stirring to create a creamy sauce without scrambling eggs.
original_steps: Pour the egg mixture over the pasta and stir to coat, ensuring the pasta is not too hot to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Stir the pasta with the guanciale and fat, allowing the water and fat to emulsify into a creamy sauce.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta, stirring quickly to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the spaghetti and gently mix to coat the pasta, ensuring the eggs do not scramble.
Mix the spaghetti with the bacon and then add the egg yolk mixture, stirring quickly to coat the pasta and create a creamy sauce.
Adjust the sauce consistency by adding more pasta water if needed, ensuring a creamy texture.
If needed, use reserved pasta water to adjust the sauce consistency.
If needed, add more pasta water to achieve the desired sauce consistency.

subgoal_definitions.title: Finish and Serve
subgoal_definitions.description: Adjust sauce consistency, add cheese and pepper, and garnish with bacon before serving.
original_steps: Serve with additional grated parmesan or pecorino and a touch of pepper for decoration.
Finish with additional cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino romano cheese before serving.
Plate the pasta and garnish with additional grated cheese and crispy bacon.
Finish with additional grated pecorino romano and black pepper before serving.
